Changes in UAE Merger Regime 


On 20 January 2025, the UAE issued Ministerial Decree No. 3 of 2025 providing details of the thresholds (the “Turnover Decision”) which trigger notification requirements to the UAE Ministry of Economy. The Decree entered into force on 31 March 2025. The Turnover Decision mandates merger filings in the following instances: If the parties meet the turnover threshold where the annual sales amount in the relevant market in the UAE exceeds AED 300 million during the last financial year or If the parties’ total market share exceeds 40% of the total sales in the relevant market in the UAE during the last financial year

UAE Courts to Start Using AI 


In line with the UAE National Strategy for Artificial Intelligence 2031 aiming at securing its place as a global leader in AI, the UAE started since the beginning of the year to integrate AI in its courts system through trials aiming at testing AI’s effectiveness in the study of legal cases. 

These trials at this stage are limited to cases where outcomes are clear-cut and require no human discretion (such as case management, translation, analysis and enforcement).

Dubai Issues New Law on the Roles of DIFC Courts 


In line with the UAE leadership vision aimed at cementing the country status and most particularly Dubai status as a centre for progressive legislations and advanced regulatory framework, the ruler of Dubai H.H. Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum issued Law No. (2) of 2025 regulating the mission and the activities of the Dubai International Financial Centre Courts (“New DIFC Courts Law”) in addition to the legal frameworks for companies operating in DIFC. 

Dubai Issues Law on the Use of the Emirate’s Emblem 


Under Dubai Law No. 1/2025, the Emirate of Dubai is the owner of the new Dubai Emblem while the Government of Dubai is the owner the new Government Emblem (“New Emblems”). Both these New Emblems symbolizing Dubai’s identity, heritage, values, principles, and vision in addition to the current emblem (together “Dubai Emblems”) are protected respectively under Dubai Law No. 1/2025 and Dubai Law No. 17/2023. 

ADGM Issues New Employment Regulations 2024 


Abu Dhabi Global Market (ADGM) issued new Employment Regulations 2024 (“New Law”), which came into effect on 1 April, 2025, replacing the previous Employment Regulations 2019 as amended (“Old Law”). Key features of the New Law include employment agreements, flexibility, probation period, working hours, Ramadan working hours, leaves, and maternity leave.

UAE implements Pillar Two - 19 Feb 2025 


The UAE has issued Cabinet Decision No (142) of 2024, introducing a Domestic Minimum Top-up Tax based on the OECD's Global Anti-Base Erosion Model Rules. This tax applies to Multinational Enterprises with an Effective Tax Rate in the UAE below 15%, following an announcement by the Ministry of Finance in December 2024. The Ministry of Finance has also issued a list of Frequently asked questions on Pillar 2 - Pillar 2 - FAQs. 

UAE Ministry of Finance Publishes Public Consultation Paper on E-Invoicing – 17 Feb 2025 

The UAE Ministry of Finance has published a public consultation paper on e-invoicing, detailing its proposed e-invoicing data dictionary. The document outlines the e-invoicing framework, provides an overview of the data dictionary, and includes a catalogue of all the data elements needed for generating, exchanging, processing, and reporting e-invoices.

New Foreign Investment Law in Saudi Arabia 


In line with Saudi Arabia’s vision 2030, the Saudi government is shaking up its legislative and regulatory landscape to incentivize foreign businesses to invest in the Kingdom the New Law covers both foreign and local investors inside and outside special economic zones and abolishes the requirement for a Foreign Investment License 

Zakat, Tax and Customs Authority (“ZATCA”) Announcements

1. Extension in the timelines of tax amnesty until 30 June – 07 Jan 2025 

On 29 December 2024, the Zakat, Tax and Customs Authority (ZATCA), following the decision of the Minister of Finance, announced an extension of the fines and financial penalties waiver initiative. The extension allows taxpayers to benefit from the waiver of fines and penalties, encouraging compliance and ensuring that due taxes are paid without the added burden of financial penalties. 

2. ZATCA Publishes Guide on Real Estate Taxation for Build, Own, Operate, and Transfer Contracts – 29 Jan 2025 

ZATCA has issued a clarification on the tax treatment of immovable property under Build, Own, Operate, and Transfer (“BOOT”) contracts. The primary aim of this guide is to provide clear and detailed instructions on understanding the various transactions involved in BOOT contracts and their associated tax implications.

ZATCA Introduces Advance Pricing Agreement Guidelines to Streamline Transfer Pricing Compliance – 17 Feb 2025 

ZATCA has published guidelines for implementing Advance Pricing Agreements (APAs) to provide a structured framework for taxpayers to establish pre-approved transfer pricing methods. The initiative aims to prevent complex, time-consuming, and costly transfer pricing disputes by offering taxpayers a way to obtain pre-determined arm's length pricing for transactions with related entities or between a head office and its permanent establishment. 

KSA Tax Treaties 

ZATCA Clarifies the Application of Double Taxation Relief under Tax Treaties – 30 Jan 2025 

ZATCA has issued new guidance on Double Taxation Relief. The guidance explains how tax treaties are applied to eliminate double taxation, ensuring compliance with international tax standards and preventing tax evasion. It clarifies the two main methods used to eliminate double taxation, which depend on the specific terms of each tax treaty.

Several new treaties and announcements have also taken place. For further details on tax treaties, please contact Group Tax team.

Legislative Reforms Aiming at Attracting FDIs 


Qatar is planning sweeping legislative reforms in line with its national development strategy published in 2024, according to which Qatar set a cumulative target of attracting $100 billion in foreign direct investment (“FDI”) by 2030. To achieve this target, Qatar has several new laws in the pipeline according to its Minister of Commerce and Economy Sheikh Faisal bin Thani Al Thani, chief among which is a bankruptcy law, a public private partnership law and a new commercial registration law, which are expected to be drafted relatively soon (in the coming weeks). In addition, these legislative reforms will include 27 laws and regulations across 17 government ministries that affect 500+ activities, . Our newsletter will keep an eye on these developments in the coming editions.

Qatar has published Pillar 2 legislation 

On 27 March 2025, the State of Qatar published in the Official Gazette, Law No. 22 of 2024 (2024 Law Amendment), amending provisions of Income Tax Law No. (24) of 2018 (as amended by Law No. (11) of 2022) , by introducing a local Income Inclusion Rule and a local Supplementary Minimum Tax Rule on multinational groups. The 2024 Law Amendment only, and not the full ITL, applies to all areas of Qatar, including to entities licensed by the Qatar Financial Centre, the Qatar Free Zones Authority, Qatar Science & Technology Park and Qatar Media City.

The General Tax Authority in Qatar has announced 100% Tax Penalty Waiver to encourage compliance – 25 Feb 2025 

The General Tax Authority (GTA) has launched a tax penalty waiver initiative aimed at encouraging voluntary compliance and fostering trust in the tax system. This initiative offers a 100% waiver on financial penalties under the Income Tax Law and the Excise Tax Law. The initiative will be effective for 6 months, starting from 1 March 2025, allowing eligible taxpayers to regularize their tax status without incurring penalties.

Electronic KYCs Implemented 

The Kingdom of Bahrain has implemented a nation-wide use of electronic KYCs (“e-KYC”) through guidelines issued on 17 February 2025 by the Central Bank of Bahrain (“CBB”). By virtue of these guidelines, all license holders may partner with e-KYC service providers approved by the CBB and integrated with the Central Registration System of the Information and E-Government Authority (“iGA”).

Bahrain issues guidance on Pillar 2 

The Bahraini National Bureau of Revenue has issued a guide explaining the Domestic Minimum Top-up Tax (“DMTT”). The guide covers key aspects such as revenue thresholds, compliance rules, exclusions, and transitional measures. The DMTT ensures that multinational companies operating in Bahrain pay a minimum of 15% tax on their profits.

Oman implements Pillar Two – 07 Jan 2025 

The Sultanate of Oman has issued Royal Decree 70/2024, introducing a Top-up Tax, marking a significant step in the development of Oman's tax system. The Top-up Tax is structured as an Income Inclusion Rule and applies to Multinational Enterprises within the scope of Pillar Two. Specifically, the tax imposes a 15% top-up on multinational companies operating in Oman whose annual revenues exceed OMR 300 million (EUR 750 million).
